The Foreign Stout is an underrated and seemingly forgotten sub-genre in the stout world. Youd think theyd be more popular since beers of the style tend to be plenty robust and complex but without the massive booziness of an imperial stout. Thats exactly what Snake River Zonker Stout is and exactly why its an excellent brew.

I poured a 12oz can into a goblet. There was no freshness date and it cost $3.40 ($0.28 per ounce).

Appearance: Deep black hue with slight brown highlights. Pours to a large, dark tan, frothy head which laces and retains tremendously well.

Smell: Chocolate syrup and black licorice although a dank, piney hop aroma is present too.

Taste: If I were to describe the beers palette without any other context you might think I was talking about a huge hefty stout, but this beer is actually more middle-of-the-road. Strong bitterness right away  similar to black coffee. Immediately it becomes sweet with a delectable flavor of black licorice and dark chocolate. The hops bite back on the finish with a noticeable bitterness, though theyre much danker this time. It really complements the dark malty character. Overall, its a tasty and well-balanced brew; Im really impressed.

Drinkability: At 6% ABV, Snake River Zonker Stout is definitely not a weak beer, yet much too light to be considered imperial by any means. Im impressed it has so much flavor and complexity for this weight and is also remarkably pleasing to drink. The mouthfeel is smooth and soft, but in no way thick or sticky. I get no alcohol taste or warming sensation, though the hops do linger momentarily. This is strong enough to stand up to a savory dinner and sweet enough to complement a dessert. Drink it as you see fit.

Score: 9/10

Growler from Bierkraft.  Very dark with lasting tan head and lace.  Rich roasted coffee and chocolate aroma with some green hop and minimal fruit.  Rich chocolaty sweetness minimal fruit and well balanced clean bitter finish.  Nice rich mouthfeel.  Excellent.

Can from Brennans. Pours an opaque black with a brown head leaving nice drops of lacing. Aroma has cocoa powder, roasted malts, licorice and coffee. Taste is of sweet chocolate, roasted and burnt malts, some lactose and faint coffee with a tanginess. Smooth and dry. Finishes sweet with some bitterness, and a bit short. This is pretty good; smooth, tasty and an easy drinker.
UPDATED: APR 17, 2013 Bottle.  Peat, coffee, chocolate and malt aroma.   Black with small head.  Sweet dark chocolate malt, coffee and ash flavor.  Nice body.  Pretty tasty.

Bottle courtesy of Atom. Thanks! Chocolate malt, smoky peat, coffee aroma. Black brown with a mall tan head. Coffee, ash, chocolate, earthy peat flavor, roasty finish. Medium body, lively carbonation.

Aroma of dark chocolate and light coffee roast with caramel malt
Pours pitch black with big frothy lasting brown head
Flavor of rich roasted malt coffee and chocolate with light caramel malt
Med body med low co2 creamy and smooth. Bitter roast finish
Excellent stout! Very glad I picked this one up
Sampled at GABF on Thursday October 11, 2012Black color, brown head. Sweet, malty, roasted scent. Sweet, coffee taste. Roasted aftertaste. Medium mouthfeel, medium high bitterness.

Can, pours a dark black, aroma is very roasty and the taste is really really well balanced and it is so smooth, lots of life to this one lots of roasty, chocolate and coffee in the taste, really enjoyable

Pours very dark brown with minimal tan head and okay lacing.  Smells of malts, molasses, and chocolate.  Tastes of roasted malt, barley, molasses, black licorice, and some bitter chocolate.  I was expecting better based on the ratings here.

Draft. Deep brown/black body. Frothy, beige head, mostly diminishing. Aroma of roasted malts, molasses, chocolate. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Nice aroma, but the beer doesnt deliver in the flavor. Ashy, slightly metallic. The bitterness and burnt notes get in the way of the malts. Average.

Pours a solid black with a thin brown head and lacing. It has a nice roasted malt aroma along with some coffee and chocolate. The flavor is slightly smokey and toasted barley and malt up front, a semisweet aftertaste, and a smooth texture.
12 ounce bottle.  Pours black with a decent tan head.  Aroma of malt, chocolate, and coffee.  Taste is roasted malt, dark bitter chocolate, and coffee.  Very nice.

Can poured into glass. Gotta love stouts out of cans. This has a nice roasty flavor with a slight bitter chocolate after taste. Aroma is mostly charred malts and chocolate. Very tasty and worth trying.

Can. Nice two fingers of frothy sticky dark tan head on a nearly black body. Dak chocolate, minerals, some oat and espresso. Flavor very much follows the aroma with dark bitter chocolate, espresso, minerally dark finish. Medium fluffy and slightly creamy body. Nice brew
Pours pitch black. beautiful pour. I was immediately excited. full bodied. really chocolatey and malty. Finishes dry and almost slightly acidic. Really loved it. wish i had more.
black coloured body with a off white head a roasted malty chocolat aroma a roasted malty caramel chocolat herby sweet bitter taste with a little alcholic bitter finish
Pours a beautiful black color with some lacing. Loved the heavy aroma of coffee and oatmeal. Pretty tasty beer.

Bottle shared by Thorpe429. Thanks Mike!

The beer appears a near black shade in the body, with a dark brown hue near the crest. The beige head is a finger thick, and leaves a good trail of lacing on the glass. The aroma is quite roasty, with scents of chocolate in there as well. Very pleasant tasting, with a good balance of roast and chocolate flavors. Medium bodied and smooth, this beer has a nice feel on the palate. Very drinkable, I would certainly have this again.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-12-2011

Pours a jet black with a tan head that fades quickly.  Aromas of coffee, chocolate, anise. Taste follows suit, with the addition of some bittering hops threw in to the mix.  A very decently put together stout.  I like it.

12oz can from Montana. Dark reddish brown with a creamy tan head. Aroma of bittersweet chocolate, caramel and light roast. Flavor is coffee, roasted malt and bitter chocolate. Medium to full body with a soft, creamy mouth feel. Really nice stout, well balanced and flavorful.

I had this bottle poured at a restaurant, so the total lack of head may not have been the fault of the beer. It is jet black with the slightest dirty-white lace.
The smell is amazing: a little black licorice, lots of molasses and ending with a little smoke.
Great tasting too, following the smell: molasses, mild hop bite and more molasses.
It seemed crisper than normal for its style and lots of carbonation.
Overall it is a great stout, though the mouthfeel was off-style.

12oz bottle pours dark brown/black with a small tan head. Aroma of chocolate, molasses, with some leather and roasted malts, hints of hops. Taste has nice roasted malts, chocolate, bitter coffee, and hops. Well balanced, a solid stout.

Poured from growler into belgian glass. Aroma is a little underwelming for the style. Picking up a little chocolate, and a bit of roasty malt. not seeing the fruitiness true to foreign stout style. Appearance spot on: dark, opaque color. Nice tan head with good retention. Nice, bold flavor, with big roasty malt presence. Finishes pretty dry. Moderate bitterness, with no fruitiness or diacetyl. Palate: medium body with a bit of creaminess. No presence of alcohol noticed. Very good example of the style overall.

zonkers!?! .. . pours a medium brown black .. light foam .. some spotty lacing .. . light coffee and wet charcoal .. . abv is done nicely .. . a good brew without real flaws, but just to simple for me .. . . im sure theres some kind of shanty clause in there...

12 oz. bottle best before January 2012.mail ordered from the brewery. Looks like a stout. The aroma is enticing. I can tell there is some hoppiness begging to break through the dense malts. There are notes of licorice, leather, espresso. Something about the flavor harkens Founders Porter, though not as delicious, which is not a knock on zonker stout, just an affirmation of the beauty that is Founders porter. This is a pleasingly dry beer with meaty flavor and finish that is ashy and sharp. Really nice stout. It lingers with something almost smoky.

Pours pitch black with ruby hues and a thick mocha head...nice lacing and retention.  Aroma has some cocoa and some dark fruit.  Flavor is very roasty with notes of coffee and chocolate...bit of dark fruit, a bit burnt.  Mouthfeel is medium and creamy with a very roasty lingering finish.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2015 [ Bottle ][ 1oz ][ @tasting ][ $0 ][ Shot glass ][ 08.15.15 ]Rich brown-black, thin tan ring for a head. Thin cocoa and bean nose, light sugar and milk chocolate along light roast. Flavor is straightforward milk chocolate, then becoming more bitter, dry roast and manure, chalky finish brings out the malt in the finish. Decent, dry, balanced.

355mL thanks to Travlr. Pour is a deeper black than expected, near ink SRM for style. Thinner tan head. Not much retention or lacing. Nose is lacto, sharp coffee, sticky vanilla bean, molasses, soy. Taste up front is thinner with big carbonation moving to cigarette ash and dirt. Not so great. My first beer from Wyoming. Not too bad of a first impression for the state with the most breweries per capita. Too bad none of them distribute past a 10 mile radius.
Bottle. Very dark brown, dark brown head, great lacing. Aroma of Hersheys syrup. Taste is chocolate syrup and espresso soda.  Very nice.

Joint tasting with Strykzone.  Pours  very dark brown tending toward black with a very attractive tan head with big bubble and a lot of sticky lacing.  Nose is roasted malts with a bit of ash, chocolate, and coffee. Bold in body and clean in the mouth The flavor mirrors the aroma with some bitterness showing.  Quite nice.

12 oz. bottle from Hayduke.  We enjoyed it together via facebook chat.  This poured almost black with a bit of red.  A nice two toned tan head.  The aroma was ash can but later chocolate arrived and grew.  The flavor was all chocolate and it was complex.  Hops would have been nice but they were barely tasted.  This beer has so much complex chocolate it might cause pimples.  It is also very nice.

12oz bottle trade from beer bill. Very nice stout. Oily black pour with dark beige head. Great aroma of chocolate/cocoa powder some roast aroma also. Goes down smooth with med heavy mouthfeel (looks like it would be thicker). More chocolate powder in taste plus Roasted stuffs. Finish is dry.  Would like to try again
This beer was pretty good got it at a place in cheyenne called suite 1901 who would have guessed wyoming could produce this

12 oz. Jet black with a lasting eighth inch of cream. Nose is coffee, cocoa, caramel, ash. Tastes of espresso, semi-sweet chocolate, green herb, charred wood, cookie dough, and vanilla. Velvety smooth, well-balanced medium body is softly carbonated, watery and easily downed.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Nonic Imperial Pint.

Appearance: Pure black with nice brown head (at first) and slight lacing. Looks almost Imperial.

Aroma: Bittersweet chocolate, molasses, licorice, roasted barley, and a light touch of alcohol.

Taste: Chocolate, coffee, molasses, with a light roasted and almost musty character. Fairly light bitterness at the end for an American Stout.

Palate: Low carbonation, pretty smooth, medium body that seems a smidgen thin for a Stout, semi-dry finish.

Overall: While a nice drinkable, even delectable Stout, I would have preferred a little more body, roasted character or bitterness (or maybe all three) to elevate this above simply "very good" status. Still quite pleased overall.

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2011 Bottle with special thanks to my parents for bringing this back for me. Pours black. Tan head. Nose/taste of roast chocolate malt, roast coffee and vanilla. Nicely roasted. Body is a little on the lighter side.
Lightly burned coffee and roasted malt aroma. Black pour with tan head and lace. Flavor is burned coffee semi sweet roasted malt and a tad o sour. A bit thin and watery but pretty nice.
Thanks to telios.  Good, but fairly standard stout.  Tasty.  Nothing wrong at all.

12 oz bottle into tulip. Pours inky black with a thin tan head. Aroma consists of coffee, chocolate-covered raisins, nice and roasty. Taste is both sweet and bitter with a hint of sour. Carbonation is medium, body could be fuller. Very nice, although I think my initial reaction was one of deep admiration and my last impressions werent as strong. Very good, nonetheless.

Bottle served in a snifter. Pours near black with a short light brown head. Sweet aroma of Ovaltine, then some light feed, other barnyard elements, and a grassy hop backdrop. The nose seems to be continually developing. Medium sweet flavor. Medium body, noticible carbonation, medium thin texture, and a roasty, light bitter finish.
A nice chocolate & spice aroma with a dark appearance and a creamy medium size head. This Stout is a wonderful blend of flavors that stays on your palate for quite a while.

12 oz. bottle in trade with Sledutah. Pored into a snifter. Small ring of tan head, good amount of lace. Nose and Flavor had burned malt, dark chocolate and coffee with a bit of cream sweetness. Finished fairly dry and hard roasted.  The only down fall is it is a little thin. But overall it is a very enjoyable stout. Thanks Craig, for putting this in our trade!!

Purchased from the Snake River website. Very glad to finally knock off this state, which brings my total up to 48. Come on OK and ND. Also, this happens to be a highly-rated FES. Score. Served in a snifter. 

Beer pours dark brown with a good off-white head. Moderate amount of lacing and a thin collar throughout. The nose is roasty and dry with some coffee notes and a bit of dry chocolate. Taste is an improvement from there, with the roast, coffee, and chocolate notes all bringing dryness but not taking it over the edge. The fact that it gets a 4.5 here is all the more impressive given that someone mentioned Two Girls One Cup while we were drinking this. Finish is dry after a medium-bodied beer. Nice and drinkable; glad we ordered this.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-14-2011

Bottle from Snojerk321.  Dark, near black pour with a thin head settling on top.  Spots of lacing trickle along the sides of the glass.  The aroma shows coffee roast, toated barley, chocolate, and nuts.  The flavor is nice and full offering much of what the aroma indicated; chocolate, slick oats, roasted espresso, and earthy hop bitterness in the finish.  This is nicely put together.  There are no off flavors, the palate is creamy but with complimenting bitterness/roasty notes.  This is just straight solid.
Black pour with small tan head. Aroma has a ton of roastiness and some cocoa and coffee. Flavor is quite roasty and a bit dry. I taste some chocolate and the hops come through.  Not bad at all.

12 oz. bottle shared by pinkfloyd4ever- thanks again, Kevin!  He brought these back from his trip to Jackson Hole, and now I get to try my first Wyoming beer.  Pours a dark brown color, basically opaque in the glass, with a small tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts, milk chocolate, dry grains, nuts, earth, and a bit of dark fruit.  Flavor is basically the same, rich, roasty, milky, and chocolaty.  Medium-bodied, with mild carbonation and a smooth, roasty mouthfeel.  Dry finish.  Really nice stout and Id like to try more from this brewer.

Draft @ Mountain Brewers Beer Fest 2010, Idaho Falls, ID. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty chocolate and coffee aroma. Roasted malty coffee flavor with hints of chocolate. Has a roasted malty bitter chocolate and coffee finish.

bottle thanks to sledutah.  Pours black with a nice, fluffy brown head.  Nose is of choclate and roasted malts.  taste is of chocolate and roasted malts as well.  Mouthfeel is medium-thin and slightly chalky.  Surprisingly good.

Bottle.  Pour is black with a medium thick head.  Aroma is rich roasted malt with loads of milk chocolate with a distant fruitiness and a touch of cocoa.  Flavor is also lightly malty with notable milk chocolate up front.  Very rich and very smooth with notes distant notes of hop and cocoa in the finish.  This is a very tasty.
Black with a large beige head. Sweet aroma with burned malt, dark chocolate and coffee. Flavor had burned malt, dark chocolate and coffee. Finished fairly dry and hard roasted.

Bottle 35,5 cl. Courtesy of yespr. Pours pitch black with a huge and frothy light brown head with excellent retention. Hard roast aroma. Medium body, hard roasted malt, vanilla and dark dried fruits. Some malt bitter finish. Lovely. 121010

12 fl oz bottle, courtesy of beerbill. Pours dark black with a huge brown head. Aroma is dark roasted malt and chocolate. Thick chocolate, bitter and slight acidic. Dark roasted malty, bitter and chocolate lingering finish. Nice one.
sample from the pitcher @ GABF on 9/18/10.  black pour with a tan head.  roast and chocolate nose.  thinner body than expected.  roasted malts throughout with more chocolate notes.  roast finish.

[Bottle] Pours very dark brown with a small brown head. Aroma is sweet, with molasses, anise, raisin, brown sugar, and dark chocolate. Taste is big on chocolate, with subtle anise and blackberry, before giving way to deeply roasted malt towards the end. A touch thin, but smooth and has a long finish. The charred malt doesnt overpower as it does with many stouts, allowing everything to meld together beautifully. A very well done and enjoyable beer.

9/7/10.  12oz bottle courtesy Cavie!  Black pour with a small dark brown head.  Sour soy sauce aroma up front with caramels and bitterness, followed by milk chocolate.  The flavor is sweeter chocolates up front followed by a light roastiness and cream.  Not bad.

bottle thanks to chuck at s&k.  pitch black with a khaki head.  roasted malts, chocolate, dark fruits, and very sweet.  heavily roasted malts, chocolate, bittersweet in the finish and a heavily roasted aftertaste.

A vigorous pour into my 25cl tulip glass produces a deeply browned, pale cocoa colored head.  The beer is a near jet black color that doesnt allow any light to pass through its depths.  The aroma smells nicely of richly toasted whole grain, lightly of dark coffee notes and amply roasted malt are all quite noticeable.  A touch of roast grain chalkiness finds its way in towards the end of the nose and some alcohol notes produce hints of Bourbon somehow.  This is a pretty straight forward roast smelling nose, there doesnt seem to be much in the way of dark sweet malt character based on the nose and in fact reminds me of a super roasty Irish Dry Stout (well see if the taste bears that out).

Dry and roasted tasting, burnt grain notes linger on the palate after my first sip and make this finish even drier.  Quite smooth tasting, but also very light bodied, this beer is quite quaffable; it is extremely light bodied in fact and definitely much like Guinness in body, though it has worlds more flavor than that beer.  Flavors of darkly roasted coffee, roasted whole grain bread crust, unsweetened cocoa powder and some roasted grain husk flavors.  There is a touch of burnt acidity to the finish, but only a touch; despite the ample roast character this manages to not be overdone at all.

This is a nice, simply focused stout; it showcases dry, roasted grain flavors without getting too harsh, too bitter, burntly acidic, or astringent.  Very nicely done, I could see myself quaffing a few pints of this beer quite easily.

West USA trip 2010. On tap @ the brewpub. The aroma has chocolate, coffee and roast. Black coloured beer with a beige head. The taste is sweet, roasted with chocolate/moccha/coffee. More bitter towards the end. A good straightforward stout.

the Dan Journal #390. Tasted 8/6/10. 12oz bottle. Opaque with a brown hue. Moldly khaki head. Aromas of toffee and cocoa dust with hints of coffee and chocolate cake. Full bodied with a great bitterness. Flavors of coffee and dark chocolate. Fudge and graham crackers. Bitter, bready and sweet on the palate. Good dark roasted toast flavor. Solid effervescence. Slight nutty and cola flavor. Great roll of the palate and a great brew!
UPDATED: JAN 25, 2016 Good stout.  Nothing bad to say but not running out and getting more quickly.  Serving: Bottle

Interesting Brew. Black pour with thin beige head. You can instantly detect the chocolate aromas that are balanced with a deep roast,

Cocoa taste, again with hints of Dark roast malts that end with a bitter/ caramel finish. The only knock I had on this stout was that I found it a little thin.

Good beer with a good punch.

12oz bottle from Discount Liquor in Evanston 
Appearance: Pours a thick black with a nice dark tan head and tons of lacing 
Aroma: Roasted malts, nutty, spices 
Taste: Roasted malts, chocolate, metallic and spices 
Not bad, something just didnt mesh together. Not well balanced. I have 5 more, so Ill re-rate if it was just that bottle.

courtesy of bocky. drank on 3/29/2010.

opaque orange tinted black with a small orange tinted off white head.

lots of roast on the nose (so much so that it is written six time in my handwritten notes!)... ash and slight smoke, licorice, molasses, chocolate and green herbal hops.

there is a fruitiness in the flavor profile which i can only identify as prune-ish... that and notes of ashy roast, molasses, scalded cream, brown sugar, chocolate, drying hops and a nice bitterness on the finish.

it is medium bodied with low carbonation. this makes it really slick and soft.

nice solid brew. 8/4/8/4/16/4.0
Not the best Stout I have ever had, but Stouts are like Sushi, its extremely hard to get them wrong.

Bottle  Pours a nice black with a small brown head that leaves quickly.  Laces well though.  Has a sweet milky aroma with hints of roast, pine, and mild hops.  A decent carbonation.  The flavor is bitter with some milky sourness to it.  A medium body.  The texture is slick.  A strange aftertaste with an okay finish.

Bottle at Maltzillas World Cup 2010 tasting. Pours black with light brown head. Aromas of roasted malts and chocolate. Roasty flavor with some chocolate and coffee. Medium body with soft carbonation and somewhat dry.

Pours solib black with a creamy brown head. Aroma of hops,roast malt, very piney and at the same time burnt. Taste is bitter up frony with a thick creamy milk sweetness. Finish of dark chocolate and resin. Very thick chewy texture, soft carbonation. At only 5.8% this beer is incredibly flavorful and full bodied.

12 oz. bottle to snifter. Pour is black and brown with a noticable tan head which dissipates to a film and ring around glass. Aroma of soy, rasian and malt with some hops there too. Taste is chaulky soy alittle molasses and vanilla in there as well. Palate is full yet thin with a chaulky and slick dry finish.

12oz. bottle.  Roasty, lightly sweet, malty aroma, with suggestions of molasses, chocolate, earthy hop, dark brown sugar and faint coffee.  Suitably opaque ebony color with a fine, lasting head of medium brown.  Flavor is full of roasty, sweet malt, plenty of semi-sweet chocolate and countering, drying bitterness throughout, with a sugary, burnt, almost smoky grain finish and lingering dark caramel tones.  Mouthfeel is smooth, thin and relatively low in effervescence, body is medium.  Coats the palate briefly.  Very tasty and drinkable, and one Id been looking to try for some time now.  It lives up to its reputation here.  Cheers to theisti!

Bottle. Black with thick tan head that wont quit. Aroma of sweet chocolate, coffee with cream, big roastedness and light earthy hops. Taste is big roasted light coffee and has big burntess. Crisp with lots of carbonation on the tongue. Finish is lingering roastedness and medium hop bite.

The beer poured black with a small head and the aroma was malty and sweet.  The flavor was malty with chocolate and toasty notes, the palate smooth with a good carb.  Overall a solid stout but nothing really stands out with this beer, so it gets a ding in the overall but otherwise very good.

this one pours jet black with a dense tan head.  Cocoa and coffee dominate the aroma.  Flavor provides roasted malt, coffee, bitter/sweet chocolate, subtle sweetness and finishes clean.  Not a heavy stout and a comfortable brew.

Folds into the glass a dark creamy ebony with a thick long lasting light brown head. Aroma is chocolate and malt. Very full bodied. Taste is full, heavy with coffee, chocolate, malt, molasses and toffee. This is one quality brew. Great as a meal unto itself or can be paired with smoked meats, grilled steak or burgers and brats.
Nice aroma, bit of molasses and coffee.  Flavor is a bit thin by comparison, but pleasant and unflawed.  Decent and drinkable.

(Bottle into English pint)  Pours a velvety black with a small tan head that fell fast, except around the edge of the glass, leaving a nice lacing as it went.  Aroma is, as expected, of the roast with some hints of chocolate and a slight hint of smoke.  Very smooth in the mouth, there is a little more jump to the carbonation than I expected, but it helped to pull the nice roast chocolate flavor forward, as well as a bit of a sharp hop bite, which was a pleasant surprise.  I would have liked a little more of a sharper finish with that bite, but the flavor just seemed to linger a hair too long.  Not the best example i have had of the style, but FAR from the worst!
Black on pour with a tan head that produced some lacing. Plenty of roast malt and chocolate on nose. This full bodied stout has plenty of malt flavor and has a smooth easy finish.
Drinking this one for breakfast this morning.  Rich aroma and flavor of roasty malts and chocolate, coffee. Bit of a metalic flavor.

From gourment beer sample pack for December, 12oz bottle.  Nice cholocate roasted head that faded slowly to start, the full flavor of darkness is solid, full, and strong for a great stout.  This brew settles slowly with the 3malt/2hops combo and solidifies itself with greatness on the pallate.  This is quite an ejoyable stout, so glad to sample it here in MA.  Great Wyoming beer. the cholate,sweetned coffe, roast barely and hints of molasses bring me to a peak of enjoyment.  Great brew.

Bottle. Pours black with a brown head that laces a bit. Aroma is full of dry roasted malts and an undertone of coffee. The flavor is similar with lots of roasted malts with an undertone of coffee and a dry finish.

Opaque, black as night, with a generous frothy brown head that left great lacing. Aromas of sweet coffee, mocha, espresso, raisins and much more. Malt sweetness dominates a complex flavor profile that features the espresso and roasted coffee. Smooth, creamy mouthfeel, low carbonation, medium body, and a slight bitterness in the aftertaste.
Bottle. Dark pour, roasty aroma with notes of chocolate & coffee. Medium bodied. Smooth, flavorful & well done

Pours opaque brown with caramel colored head.  Lots of lacing.  Aroma is malts, coffee, roast, and some sweetness. Smooth, slightly oily mouthfeel.  A decent stout indeed.  Reminds me of several others, all good ones.  Not sure why, but Deshcutes Black Butte Porter comes to mind, despite the style difference.  This is a decent stout indeed, above average.
black pour with a small dense light brown head. aroma of coffee, dry taste is that of burnt black coffee. verry bitter finish.

Pours dark brown almost opaque.  Thick dark tan head discipates slowly but lingers.  Aroma is toasty, roasty with some fruity esters.  Big full malty mouthfeel with a dominate roasty finish that ends somewhat astringently.  A very enjoyable dry stout.

This beer came in my beer club. Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured thick, black and oily with a large very dark brown head. The aroma was chocolate, toasty malts, light fruits and port wine. The flavor was toasty, fruity and had a strong cocoa element followed b port wine and coffee. The beer turns a bit dry and very bitter towards the long and roasty finish. Full bodied and smooth. Very good.

Via perfect 10th trade.  Great looking deep brown brew. The aroma is most excellently roasted with a bit of coffee & hint of molasses sweetness and ash. Roasty grain, bakers chocolate, dark semi-sweet chocolate, bit of nutty. Very good. Med mouthfeel, well carbonated. Tasty!
Pours almost black, with very little head. Rich flavor, notes of coffee, and burnt carmel. A nice stout and is very drinkable. Thumbs up.

12 ounce bottle courtesy of IrishBoy. Thanks! Pours a very auburn tinted brown color with a moderate creamy tan head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma of chocolate, roasted malts, cream and leafy bitter hops. Taste is roasted malts with a fair bit of smoke, some chocolate, caramel and a hoppy finish. Very smooth and creamy. Medium bodied. Good, well made stout.

Yummy! Great stout. Poured with a nice sized tan head and good lace. Color is opaque. Aroma is exactly as it should be: nice and roasty, malty, and a bit earthy. Ditto flavor. Add a little chocolate and roastiness and this is truly delicious. Great finish. No off flavors. Satisfying. Body is just fine with great carbonation. Good clean finish. Drinkable beer.
Bottle from Cavie.  Black pour with a brown head.  Lots of coffee aroma.  Big chocolate flavor with lots of coffee notes and roasted malts.  Nice finish.
Bottle courtesy of BückDich. Dark dark black pour. Heavy dark chocolate smell. Coffee malts. Taste is bittersweet. Roastedness for sure. Bitter finish.

12oz bottle thanks to irishboy.   First Wyoming rating, and a very nice beer.   Black with a medium tan head that leaves lots of clingy lace and a ring of foam around the glass.   Creamy chocolate aroma, with some dustier cocoa powder and dry bread.   The flavor is sweet and chocolatey, but with enough roasty bitterness to be pretty well balanced.   Full and smooth mouthfeel.   Seems much richer than 5.8% actually, though the alcohol is not really hot.   Ill definitely be stopping by the brewery when I go to Jackson Hole.

12 oz bottle purchased at Blue Max in Burnsville, Minnesota. Best enjoyed by July notched on the label. Based on the presence of some hops, I assume this is 2010? Pour is deep black with a pretty one inch dark tan head. Head falls quick with minimal lacing. Aroma of roasty charred malt with some raw cane sugar sweetness. A bit of earthy leafiness behind that. Taste is big or the char roastiness to start, followed by burnt espresso and finishing with a mild cane sugar sweetness. Pine hops come into it mid taste and help finish it out with some nice bitterness. Finish is lasting and a bit on the milky / leafy side. Weird combo, but works for this beer. Palate is medium thin, a bit watery for the big roast taste, but it does make this easy drinking. Not a totally true FES in my experience (this is much more balanced, thinner and less sweet than others I have had in the style), but I still enjoyed it quite a bit.

Special thanks to Ditmier. Pours a somewhat watered black with minimal head. Faint aromas of chocolate and roast. Flavor has the same notes but is weak and uninteresting. The label on this bottle kicks ass though and that counts for something in my book.
Bottle with thanks to Matt. Light chocolate aromas hover over a dark brown body that also supports a thin tan head. Flavor is watery chocolate with a little bit of a dark fruit presence.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Sampled at GABF 2009.  Pours black with a light tan head.  Dark chocolate and coffee aromas.  Coffee, oatmeal, and chocolate flavors.  Well-balanced.  Very good flavor for a beer under 6%.

My 1st rating from Wyoming  &  #1700 for my  USA beers! Big thanks to douglas88. 

12oz short bottle.  Aroma of rich, sweet, deep roasted malts.  Wow, this beer is loaded with malt.  Onyx black pour, with a dark brown head.  Ooh, legs on the glass.  Nice fruit and coffee scent.  Flavor of black patent malts.  Lots of them.  Huge roast, it just tastes black.  Awesome!  Finishes with a nice bitter chocolate, roasted malt, and bitter hops. Very well balanced, a very well made Foreign Stout.     Fruity essence as well.  I would love to see how this beer would age as it seems to be filtered.  A bourbon variety would also be very interesting.  Cheers!

From the Jug at the GABF Colorado Convention Center, Denver 11/10/2008
Fruit and some roast aromas. Black smooth and slightly rich on the palate with a coffee roast finish.

12 oz. bottle. Dark brown/black with a beige to tan head. Head is active at first, but fades pretty quickly. Little to no lace. Nice dry flavor, with nuts, caramel, coffee and a hint of chocolate. Mouthfeel is a little weak--I want just a little more chewiness in there. Finish is dry with some hop bitterness. Very nice overall. Had it at the brewery several years back while on vacation. Thanks to the in-laws for bringing some back from their vacation. Though they dont drink, they loved the food at the brewery. Good job, SRB!

12 oz Bottle.  Pours rich and dark with a small brown head which fades fairly quickly.  Aromas of roasted coffee and chocolate.  Mouthfeel is full bodied and rich flavors of coffee and bitter chocolate coat the palate.  The finish lingers impressively.  Overall an excellent stout.

Dark black pour with creamy tan head.  Coffee aroma with some dark chocolate, light roastiness. Flavor is chocolate coffee with a deep, roasty finish.Thick and full on the palate with nice mouthfeel. Very nice stout.

My first beer from WY.  Beer courtesy of Secret Santa Summer 09.  Good oatmeal aroma.  Black body with tan head.  Flavor was mainly a good dose of oatmeal with medium creamy texture to it.  Easy on the palate.  Enjoyable stout.  Thanks, Buckeye Boy, for this beer!
Poured very black, smooth, roasted malts, coffee, nutty, slight chocolate, dry finish.

12oz shorty bottle.  Pitch black with a nice beige-brown head.  Mellow chocolate coffee aroma.  Thick and rich, with lots of roasted and chocolate malt flavor.  Quite thick and definitely better than your typical Stout.  There is a pleasant bitter, sandy balance as well.  Dark fruit and bitter dark chocolate aftertaste.  Right on!

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown with a medium size brown head. Aroma of espresso, roasted malts, unsweetened chocolate, and molasses. Flavor is of roasted malts, cocoa, and a hint of espresso. Nice lasting bitterness. Im impressed. Snake River did a really good job with this one.

The pour is opaque black with some nice brown head. The nose is mostly roast with a bit off coffee and cream. The is an underlying herbal hope note as well. The flavor is strong roast with a touch of sweet right up front, and then a blast of roasted malt and hoppy bitterness. Full, rich body. Dry finish. As good a stout as any.
I loved this beer. Very maly, rich roast. Elements make it taste a lot like an imperial stout. Nice hop note comes in with the finish.

12oz bottle bonus.  Pours a deep coffee brown almost black with a 2 finger thick tan head that left decent lacing.  Nose is mostly dry roasted malts, cocoa dust and some dried dark fruits in the background.  Flavor was medium dry with some bitter-sweet chocolate and a light hop bitterness in the finish, pretty good overall.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours black with a large foamy brown head.  The aroma opens with a nice dose of roasted malt and semi sweet chocolate.  The flavor is roasted malt, a hint of ash, dark chocolate, dry espresso, and a slight hop bitterness.  Medium bodied and very well balanced.  This is a solid foreign stout and would happily revisit this if it were available.

Bottle in Jackson, Wyoming. Best beer of the trip! This was a delicious stout. Perfect black pour with a nice head. Dry, chalky, clean and roasty flavor, nice espresso notes. Thick body, good coal and black malts, with just a touch of hop bitterness at the finish. Wonderfully crafted.

Bottle courtesy of douglas88  my first from Wyoming.  Pours pitch black with a foamy 2 finger mocha colored head that leaves spotty lacing.  The nose is milk chocolate, roasted malt and faint dark fruits.  The taste is burnt malt, ash, dark chocolate and espresso.  Medium creamy mouthfeel.  Good stout  thanks again Douglas for sending this my way!

12 oz bottle courtesy of ditmier. Thanks. Pours an opaque black color with a frothy tan head. The aroma is rich with coffee and dark roasted malts. The flavor is big and bold with cocoa, chocolate, coffee, wlanuts and dirt. The finish is long, dry and earthy. The mouthfeel is full and creamy. Overall: A very chocolaty stout, very tasty. Loved it.

12oz thanks to Douglas88.  Pours a black with brown edges and a nice dark tan head.  Aromas of dark fruit, chocolate and heavy roast.  Flavors of roasted malt, chocolate, and a fairly hopped finish.  Overall a pretty good beer, i wish we still had in the Denver area.  Thanks again Douglas!

Very dark brown with a thin tan head that dissipates into a thin tan layer thats there for the duration.  Aroma of roasted malts, sweet malts, chocolate and soy sauce.  Taste of roasted and dark malts with some chocolate mixed in.  Dry finish with a weird sulfur like aftertaste.

Courtesy of Nbutler11, thanks Nick! It is pitch black with a huge, brown and creamy head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee and dark fruits. The flavour has a light sweetness, notes of roasted malt, coffee, chocolate and preserved berries. It is very charming and fullbodied, nice indeed!
12 oz bottle at Woodshop.  Dark pour with smallish head.  Aromas of roasted and burnt malts.  Similar flavors with more roasted malts.  Pretty good.

Sweet bonus courtesy of ditmier. Pours deep dark with full inch tall mocha head. The mild aroma has notes of roastiness moving to burnt malts and a touch of earthiness.  Nice roasty taste to go along with supporting notes of sweet malts and molasses. Midway it gets toasty leading into some dry malt astringency. Pretty nice.

Bottle.  Pours a black color with a thin brown head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, and roasted malt. Taste of roasted malt, light hops, cocoa, and coffee. The body is more like a porter. Has a dry, semi bitter finish.

Bottle courtesy of Ibrew2or3. Pours a pitch black color with a thin tan head. Aroma is roasted and malty with notes of brown sugar, ripe dark fruit, some hints of coffee. Flavor is roasted and malty with notes of coffee, toffee, ripe dark fruit and some anise. Generally medium to full body with a roasted and malty finish.

Thanks Ibre2or3 for the share.  Pours motor oil black with energetic dark head.  Nose is licorice, bitter coffee, and some sweet milk.  Flavor is lots of coffee with some licorice.  Finishes with some bitter and bite.  Very nice.

Bottle, courtesy Ibrew2or3. Pitch black pour, creamy dark tan head, very creamy lacing. Nose is big dry roast, tons of coffee, some chocolate. Rich flavors, coffee, very dry finish, with some licorice, and sweet chocolate. Very drinkable and balanced. Of all the Wyoming beers Ive had, this is easily the best.

courtesy of tasting group.
Pour black with mocha like head.
Aroma of roasted malts, bitter notes of chocolate and light coffee.
Taste, malty with thick chocolate mouthfeel, not overly bitter with notes of coffee and some dark fruits.
Bottle shared by Daknole. Dark brown with not much head. Nice roasted chestnut aroma, other nuts, and some mild coffee notes. Lots of chicory and roasted roots in the flavors. Drinkable and dry.

bottle. black pour, small tan head.  Aroma has a ton of roastiness and some cocoa and coffee.  Flavor is quite roasty and a bit dry.  I taste some chocolate and the hops come through in the this stout fairly well.  Just too roasty, dry and bitter for me.
(12oz bottle) Courtesy of IrishBoy. Pours a frothy, beige head and an opaque body. Nose of strong coffee. Flavour of cold coffee, ash tray and dirt. Good. 7/3/6/3/13

2008 Bottle - Pours black with a small tan head...aroma is toasty malt, white chocolate, fruit...flavour is nicely bitter on the front end, very dry, char char bitter, dry fruit but not malty...smells bigger than it tastes, but is still very nice...way to go wyoming...

12 oz bottle thanks to douglas88. Pours black with some red-orange highlights and a nice tan head. The aroma is very roasty with lots of cold coffee notes and a few subtle hints of vanilla, bitter chocolate, and leather. The flavor is very roasty and full of coffee notes, just as I would expect given the aroma. There is a little bit of a sweet toffee and caramel undertone that keeps things in balance. Some dark fruit notes shine through once in a while, especially in the distant aftertaste. The finish is ash and roasted nuts. Pretty good beer.

12 oz bottle

Thanks to Santa for sending this a few weeks ago.  I now can not only cross Wyoming off my list of states I can also say I have tried one of the best foreign stouts.  The style percentage may not bear it out but in my mind this is almost on par with most imperial stouts.

Aroma / Appearance - Deep black and almost oily it slinks out of the bottle.  As it settles into the glass a creamy beige head begins to accumulate.  The smell of dark bitter chocolate, black coffee, and anise chokes the senses to the point that this has better aroma than a poorly done imperial stout and might even hold its own against some of the better ones.

Flavor / Palate - The mouthfeel backs up the advertised experience.  Creamy and filling the taste of anise, black coffee, and bakers chocolate forms a memorable profile.  A woody aftertaste sticks to the back of the throat.  Well balanced this is among the best stouts available on the market.  I would put it in my personal Top 20 of non big beers.
Very solid stout. Large body, nice hop profile that is complimented by the roast barley. That said nothing spectacular.

This poured a nice dark dark brown color with a light tan head. Aroma was mainly coffee like, not to much sweetness at all. Flavor was much the same, very dry but not burnt, slight hints of dark chocolate as well.

Bottle. Pours black with a small tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, and a touch of molasses. Flavor is rich roasted malts, dark chocolate, lightly roasted coffee, and some vanilla. Medium body with a smooth and dry finish.  Decent brew
Black with a cream head.  Aroma is light smoke, chocolate, roasty, caramel.  Taste is roasty, light chocolate, light hoppiness.
Thanks to ajm for the bottle.  Pours a rich black color with a trim brown head.  Loaded with bakers cocoa and lightly roasted coffee.  Very dry for a stout but well balanced.  Well done Wyoming.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2008 Bottle from Discount Liquor in Evanston, WY.  Smells and tastes rich and dry.  Very nice texture of powdery dark chocolate.  Not very coffee-like or roasty, but still smooth and balanced.  Really feels like a Stout to me, not a Foreign Stout - a little thick for that.  But Im not Professor Q. Edmund Bierstein, so I wont insist on it.
Thick brown head and lacing on black beer. Good roasted malt aroma, more coffee and dark malt than chocolate. NIce flavour with a sof sweetness and a bit of dark bitterness. Nice drinkable stout.

Bottle.  Pours a very dark black, almost looks like used motor oil.  The head is rather large, creamy, clingy and is dark tan in color.  Taste is of coffee, roasted malt, chocolate and caramel, with a dry and bitter finish.  Is well balanced with a good mouthfeel.  Very easy to drink and is quite enjoyable.  One of their best beers and worth having again.

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2009 May have been infected as there was a smell of gym socks, used gym socks. The flavor was a bit less offensive. Creamy and attractive looking. RERATE: Thanks to Richard for sending another bottle to me as the first was crap. Roasty and coffee and nice smooth nose and flavor.

Scored this as a bonus in a recent trade with jake65.  Thanks Jake!  12oz bottle pours a slightly viscous, opaque black with a lacing, creamy tan head.  Aroma is fairly mild, slight toast, roasted malts, some dark chocolate in the aroma with just a hint of pepper.  Flavor has more chocolate, a bit of Belgian yeast, toast, coffee, brown sugar and a little maple.  Finish is dry and smooth.  Pretty good, but I’m not sure what separates this as a foreign stout.

Another of the beers received in a trade with jake65. Pours a deep, almost black, shade of brown with a wispy dark head. Nice smooth slightly bitter mouthfeel.  Medium bodied & dry. I would have thought it would have been listed as a dry stout. Malty, chocolate nose. Taste is malty, bakers chocolate & bitter coffee. Some vanilla bean in the background.

On cask at the brewery. Deep black with a large tan head that lingers. Huge chocolate malt aroma, with hints of coffee, dark fruits, and dried berries. Taste starts with bitter toasted malt, then becomes more bitter, before coffee and chocolate kick in near the end. Lingering coffee taste. Very tasty stout.
Bottled: Dark stout that pours black with tan lacing. Smells chocolaty and taste of roasted chocolate malts with light hops. Delicious!

12oz a gift from Wetherel, shared with my gf cyn.  I thought of this because dalekliz just went to the brewery.  Pours black with a big puffy tan head.  Nose is full of dark malts and the taste is sweet, with lots of roasty coffee notes.  Pretty nice.

Pours dark brown, with a light brown head. Aroma is chocolate, coffee, and roasted malt. Flavor is roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, and some vanilla. Body is a bit too light. Thanks to footbalm for this bottle.

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2008 Bottle brought back from the Boise Co-op by footbalm. Pours a very dark brown with a small light brown head. The aroma is full of coffee and berries. The taste was nice; loads of coffee, sweet berries and vanilla, some milk chocolate, and overall a fairly dry and a medium body. A nice beer.

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2008 This beer comes with the a nearby stores heaping praise.  In fact, the young clerk that pointed it out when I asked for recommendations pointed at it without a moments hesitation.  Profound!  Will the beer match the clerks reverence?  His devotion?  The Zonker Stout is totally black on the pour, in or out of the light, with a thin espresso cream colored head.  This lacing, as the beer is slowly sipped, keeps a sturdy grip on the glass.  Good strong lacing for a good strong beer.  The smell is rich and floral, most familiar with a front of raw and unground coffee beans - smooth and pleasing, even to someone that would rather take a cup of tea than coffee.  The malt flavor is, obviously, very heavy handed here, but not excessively so.  Some beers have malts that seem to discipline the drinker, giving him a slap here and there, but this is appropriately balanced.  An inflating bubble of dark chocolate stretches and squirms to make a stand, but the malt keeps it from popping onto the palate.  The aroma also has a wet, thick consistency like wet paint.  The flavor takes a different tack, initiation with coffee and fig flavors for a blend of dark, bitter and sweet, but has a clear bias for the coffee flavors.  The end of the sip contains a slithering river of dark chocolate that immediately bites the back of the throat, calling out for cold milk to free it from your esophagal tissue.  I find the Zonker stout to be more bitter than most stouts, especially since the aftertaste is so grounded in dark, high % dark chocolate flavors.  The palate is flimsy and light bodied, though, which is a bit strange considering the otherwise hulky sides of this beer.

Big thanks to BückDich for this tasty stout.  ark with  smallish head.  Very coffee aroma, molasses, malts, slight cocoa, and roasted.  Flavor is malty, anise, molasses, some milk, and chocolate. Smooth body.  Very nice example of a stout.

On tap at brewpub.  Drinkable, but very robust flavor.  Moderate roast combine with a bitter finish and milk chocolate.  Smooth, soothing palate...pretty damn good stout.  Rare to find such a small, flavorful beer.

12 oz bottle.  Dark brown with a trace of beige foam.  Nose is mild coffee and grape.  Zingy carb, medium light.  Taste is coffee, lime and lime peel with a hint of chocolate on the back end.  Finish a bit stale.
I had this after my shift at work today and it was very satisfying. Pours thick and delicious.

Thanks to Buckeye Boy for the bottle. Pour reddish black with a thin tan head. Malty coffee, roasted grain aroma. Smooth roasted grain, coffee, chocolate malt taste. Finishes clean and dry. Very nice, well balanced dry stout.
Poured black, brownish head.  Roasts dominate flavor with cocoa.  Very rich tasting.  Nice hop presence. Body a tad thin, very good.
July 2007 - Nice looking dark pour with fluffy head. Smell of lactic and roast. Flavor was rich chocolate with roast and a milky, chalky finish. Smooth mouthfeel with a little chalkiness. Good beer.
Black with fluffy off white head and some wonderful lacing.  Chocolate aroma.  roasty malts and chocolate. refreshing clean finish.

Black with a small brown head. Strong chocolaty malt smell. Lightly carbed and a med. body. Rich, roasted malt flavor here with hints of mocha. Finishes on the dry side. A most tasty stout, this should be a regular in my fridg.   8405
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Bottle sent by bitterbill on BA, thanks!  Poured basically impenetrable black with a medium lasting tan head.  Smell is dry, dark roasty malt and a dark chocolately cocoa element.  Taste is dryish dark roastiness with some sort of big hop presence and/or metallic taste, which grew on me.  Medium mouthfeel to very slightly full with medium carbonation.  Pretty nice and a bit unique.  Definitely worth trying, and I enjoyed this one overall.

1-12-08 bottle. 
Creamy black in color.  Nice watery tan head and a little lacing.  Smells of roasted creaminess with nuts and maybe a hint of marshmallows too.  Hop presence is very nice and quite a fun surprise in this stout.  Nice palate.  A but thin.  Would like to try again. Drinkable and smooth!

12 oz bottle. Pours thick cloudy black with deep tan head.  Aroma is very pleasant, the initial burst of smell is the roasted barley,with a creamy chocolate scent near the end. Flavor is much the same, very well balanced mix of roasty malts and a hint of bitterness at the finish.  The body is very smooth, with a somewhat sticky palate. Delicious stout, very easy to drink, looking forward to the rest of the 6-pack.
12oz, just grabbed this on a whim and was pleasantly surprised, nice brown head, drinking this is a breeze with a great balance of roastiness and bitterness from the hops, just a great surprise.
This is a really solid stout. Nice strong aroma, flavor and aftertaste. Thick, slightly hoppy, and tasty. A great beer, but you need the six pack, because it grows on you.

12oz Stubby

Got this as an extra from the tremendous trader known as BitterBill, thanks Bill. Zonker Stout pours midnight black and the only highlights appear when its directly backlit. The tan head rose to two fingers as I poured. As the head eventually settled to a thick crown it left sticky drink lines on its way down. Good looking stout.

The smell on this beer is definately inviting. Roastiness starts things off and are quickly accompanied by bittersweet chocolate, cream, and cocoa. The roastiness takes the biggest piece of the aroma. Although chocolate makes a strong showing toward the backend. The aroma just pulls you in.

The flavor runs the same gamut as the aroma. The roastiness is present and takes center stage but the lactic creaminess and cocoa show themselves with authority. Pure unadulterated bittersweet chocolate rounds things off on the swallow leaving the sweet followed by the bitterness. A really nice stout.

Medium bodied with a small but perfect amount of chewiness. A roasty bitterness on the finish. This beer glides through the mouth at its own pace letting the myriad of flavors come through.

This is a very easy stout to put away. If i could buy this locally it would be a mainstay in the fridge but unfortunately this is my only bottle and its just about gone.

Zonker Stout is one of the better American stouts Ive had in awhile. Id like to try more offerings from Snake River. If theyre half as good as Zonker theyd be quality.

12/14/07

Bottle from jake65 - thanks, Jake!  Room-filling aroma of syrupy dark chocolate and roast.  Salty licorice and lesser vanilla.  Pitch pour with a scant, lacing light brown head.  Taste is heavy roast, medium-strong bitterness with a delicious ashy finish.  Bodys a bit watery but the aggressive, robust roast more than compensate.  Nutty with a splash of malted milk and angular grain.  Aftertaste is very short.  Initially crisp but quickly turns pretty flat.  Great stuff!

Bottle via trade with Jake65. Aroma of roasted malt, charred grain, licorice and juniper. Pours Almost black with deep brown highlights. Flavor has a nice amount of lightly roasted malt, milk duds and vanilla. Medium bodied with a fairly lingering bitter finish. Thanks Jake!

Bottled. Beer is very dark brown, nearly opaque. Head is initially smallish, tan, frothy/creamy. Diminishes mostly but sticks around.

The aroma is initially pretty engaging, but warms/breathes its way downhill. Malty with moderate notes of chocolate milk, husky roasty grain, toasted nut; Hoppy with a light note of resin, moderate and pointy herbal note thats reminiscent of weed; Yeasty with a light note of dish rag and a trace of baby diaper cheese; Miscellaneous traces of brine, marshmallow and vanilla.

The flavor is moderately sweet, lightly/moderately bitter, lightly acidic with a long, moderately bitter, light/moderately sweet finish. Camp fire smoke in the retros.

The body is medium/full, the texture is velvety and the carbonation is lively.

Not crazy about the dish rag/pot/husk combo. Unclean and hard to stay with.

Thanks Jesse! Zonker pours blackish brown w/ just a shallow froth that goes away just as fast as it came. All that remains is a little isalnd of spatter. Aromas of dark chocolate and mild roasts. Full nectar w/ ample residual effers creating a wonferful velvety texture. Nice! Big and malty w/ a moderate roast component balanced by soft, fruity, dark chocolates. A mild hop profile helps out a bit also. Life is like a box of chocolates says Forest. If they all turned out Zonkers Id be a happy Gnome. The finish is long w/ lingering roasted cocoa and a touch of sweet. Overall: you were right Jesse, this stuff is amazing. Very rich yet well balanced.

Pours black with a medium sized brown head.  Aroma full of cocoa, along with brown sugar, raisins, and a subtle earthiness.  The faint earthiness in the aroma comes through more strongly in the flavor, along with bittersweet chocolate, prunes, and espresso in the finish.  Very good.

Poured a solid jet black color with a tan soapy head The nose was earthy and chocolaty. The taste started with milk chocolate, faint vanilla/hazelnut flavors and nice espresso notes. The finish was a mix of hops and bitter cocoas. Very balanced, very good.
