Aroma of malt, hops and molasses.  Deep , almost black color.  Flavor strongly hopped with a hint of citrus and herb, maybe mint, maybe rosemary.  As luscious on the palate as German chocolate cake.  Almost feels like this beer should be dessert, but the alcohol content and fresh aftertaste make it suitable with meals. . . Im thinking something Mexican.

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2007 From a bottle.  Poured dark black, with a nice tan head.  Great lacing.  Aroma was a bit of chocolate and coffee.  Smooth taste, well balanced.  A bit of a coffee after-taste.  A nice, solid stout, but nothing remarkable.
On tap at Flying Pie Boise, Pours out a light black topped with a light tan head. Nice aroma of roast and coffee. Tast of a little bitter and dark roast.

Enjoyed with aofoxxy in Columbia SC (sort of like a dorm room is right!).  Oily appearance, and downright frothy.  Preamble to a good night with a new friend.  Featured a smooth satisfying finish, and left me wanting more, more, more.  From a bottle.
Bottle, after the date, no head at all, I mean none. This beer is black, totally black. It has a light smell and sweet roasted oak taste.

Bottled.  Poured mahogany with light sediment floating around and a short layer of beige head.  Aroma was of sweet roasted barley and burnt black patent and chocolate malts.. some other sweetness in there, but I couldnt pick it out.  Flavor had an odd blend of sweetness and burnt notes.. enjoyed it, though.. flaked oats responsible for the sweetness, and day-old coffee grounds and some dark chocoate for the deeply-roasted/burnt part.. rather long burnt finish with some espresso bitterness.  Medium-bodied at most on the palate with an OK flow to it.  Decent brew, but nothing great going for it.

Sampled on draught at the brewpub in Jackson, Wyoming. Pours a semi opaque dark brown brew with a light tan head that quickly dissolves to a fine film. Little lacing on glass side. Aroma of milk chocolate, sweet dark molasses, toasted multi-grain malt, coffee and a touch of flowery hops. Taste is full bodied, creamy and smooth with a slight mocha flavor. Finish is slightly dry with a fresh roasted coffee aftertaste.
Loads of roasted malt.  Some oatmeal and popcorn, thick and heavy, but no complexity.  Black. Simple but good.  Nice palate.

Pours pitch black with a medium sized tan head. Retention is good with plenty of sticky lace left behind. Nose is mainly roast followed by chocolate and some blackberry notes. Body is medium, lightly oily with a hint of tartness, light chalkyness. Roastiness is nice, chocolate, faint coffee flavors, dark fruits and some black patent notes as well. Hops are evident as well maybe some pine and grass? Lighlty musty. Finish is dry, roasty and a touch chalky. A nice Stout indeed! Props to eaglefan538 for bringing this one home! Thanks Brian!!
Very dark brown beer.  Well done roasted malt nose with the usual chocolate and coffee undertones.  Roasted malt body with a sweet character.

Bottle courtesy of Duane. Almost black with huge beige head. Aroma and flavor dominated by coffee and roast. Some residuel sweetness through the middle, otherwise hard for me to get past the big coffee character.
on tap -pours a thin tan head and black color. Aroma is dark malt-faint licorice.  Taste is dark malt-coffee/smoky/faint licorice, roasty, some acidic.  OK carbonation.

Yum Yum poured a dark brown almost black good head and lacing.  Aroma was of chocolate and coffee also some darker fruits in there.  Flavor was some dark fruits coffee chocolate which i think gave it a little biter flavor.  Very good beer.

Poured a deep brown color, nice tannish type head, huge, good lacing, nice look. The aroma was coffee, light cocoa, dried fruits. The flavor was bitter cocoa, dried fruits, perhaps a touch of coffee or some roasted malts (not as much as the aroma, though), nice combination. The mouthfeel started a tad light, but seemed ok by the end, dry finish, some acidity too?

Bottle pours black with creamy head.  The aroma is of rich coffee with a hint of chocolate.  The flavor is of dark malt with coffee and dark chocolate notes.  It is a bit on the watery side.  The finish is a bit on the mild side for a stout.  Not bad but does not stand out at all.

Dont know what a foreign stout is but I do know this is very good. Easy easy drinker which I appreciate. Nice roastiness flavor balanced well with hops. Just goes to show ya that a stout doesnt have to be BIG to be great.
bottle.  black with than head.  nice lacing.  weet aroma of oat, raosted malts, chocolate, floral hops.  small body.  coffee, sour malts, hoppy.   mildly bitter.
roasted malty flavor, pours very dark, medium brown head, full bodied, one of the best Ive had.
Pours near black with a huge cascading head. Fair lacing. Aroma of roasted coffee, chocolate and some musty earth. Taste is bitter; coffee and earth. Medium to heavy body. Dry finish. Loved it.

Pours black with a huge bubbly head that lies somewhere between tan and brown.  Looks great, and the aroma indicates that this stout is pretty strong.  Caramel and toffee come out first, but theres a distinct hop presence that melds with those aromas beautifully.  Theres a little dark chocolate and roast behind that, but theyre muted.  Taste is slightly astringent at first, like a porter would be, but that is quickly stopped by a strong wallop of chocolates, mild South American coffees, caramel, toffee and toast.  Tastes a little milky on the throat followed by a significant roast coffee tastes, and bitter roasted hop flavor.  Some say this is watery, which I wont argue as its a little thin.  But its wonderfully creamy and very smooth to the point where Im not even worried about the body.  This is just a great stout!

Bottle, poured a deep black with a slow to form tan head that disapates quickly.  Aromas of burnt malts, coffee.  Flavor is similar, nothing very exciting.  Very, very thin, almost water like consistency.  Bitter finish.  A dissappointing brew.
user_location: The Land of Milk and Honey, Ohio, USA

text: Bottle. Courtesy of stoutlover72. Thanks, Garrett, for my first Wyoming beer (and 10th Foreign Stout)! Jet black pour. Sturdy dark brown froth on the surface. Nose is roasty malts, cacao, light lactic notes, and dark choco notes. Taste is sweet with milk chocolate, roasted malts, faint coffee, light lactic tartness, and subtle hops. Body is light-medium and creamy in spots. Some dryness towards the finish and a bit of lactic tartness and astringency. Finishes with more chocolate, light lactic notes, roasted malts, and creamed coffee. Delicious!

12oz btl. Black pour with brown edging, two finger tan head, fades out light a dying star, very slowly - then suddenly its just gone. Lacing left behind is in fair quantity though, like wheat malt that springs forth at the first sign of oxygen. Aroma is of light malts of the chocolate and lightly roasted variety, along with fresh skim milk. Flavor is similar, but with an addition of musty old hops that  show their face towards the finale, finishing with a touch of sweetened creamer and chocolatey malts, some roastiness. Balanced, decent.

12-oz. bottle.  Pours opaque with a small quickly diminishing light brown head, fair lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (roasted, toast, caramel), light hops (grass), average yeast (dough, leather) with notes of tar, charcoal, dark rich chocolate and heavy roasted coffee.  Average duration, moderate sweetness, light acidity and bitterness; heavy roasted straw, toasted meal malt flavor accentuated by coffee, chocolate and caramel.  Full bodied, slick texture, soft carbonation and a bitter finish.

Just about black with large foamy brown head.  Aroma is dark chocolate and roasted malt.  Flavor is mostly semi-sweet cocoa.  The lasting finish has a dry, slightly bitter, coffee bean finish (like sucking on coffee beans).  The hop bitterness is well blended, almost hidden with the other flavors.  Full body, smoth on the palate.  Overall this is a well balanced brew with a very roasty and robust flavor. --  I just happened to find this beer on the singles shelf.  It was the last one and I didnt see any six packs.  Too bad, this is a really nice brew (especially at this price!).  This would go great with any rich dessert (e.g. chocolate, cherries, raspberries, cheesecake, etc.).  

12 oz bottle, $1.35+tax from Rivers Bend.
Nice dark brown black with a good medium head.  Nose is malty roasty and good with some sweetness.  Taste is nice roasted malt with some mocha hints.  Full mouthfeel finishes warmingly.  Good stout.

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2006 Nice pour, nearly black with full, creamy, dark tan, lasting head with minimal lacing.  Nose is sweet for a stout, especially a foreign; cocoa, chocolate, malt (like the malt from a chocolate malt), roast and hop character backing.  Flavor is completely different from nose; starts sweet, malt and cocoa, then an onslaught on rich roast, followed by coffee and dark chocolate.  Hop bitterness is moderate with some hop earthiness.  Palate dries out as the flavor progresses with a medium body, but a mouthfeel that feels fuller due to the soft carb. and round.almost chewy texture.  Finishes roasty, with a light coffee acidity and dry feel, almost burnt.  Pleasantly sweet for a foreign stout but refreshing.  By far the best beer from a marginal brewery.

12oz bottle (thanks to Jah noth) poured black in color with a small light brown head. Had a very nice roast and chocolate aroma to it along with some toffee and hop notes that come trough ever so slightly. The taste had a good amount of bitterness with a strong roast flavor and a semi dry finish. Overall a good complex stout that is worth the try.

12 oz bottle via indianared (thanks ken!). Pours a motor oil like thick black with a large tan head. Nose has notes of vanilla, chocolate, coffee. Flavor is the same with no sweetness. Mediumbodied, silky mouthfeel followed by a somewhat dry burnt finish. Astringant aftertaste. Lots of bitter coffee roastiness in the aftertaste.
GABF 06.  Aroma is coffee and roasty.  Taste is bitter roasted malts, coffee, what you would expect.  Medium body.  decent.

Appears black with a small dark tan head that slowly fades into a small cap. Tons of scattered lace is left around the glass.
Smell is of chocolate milk, malt balls, vanilla, caramel, and coffee with a hint of anise.
Taste is of the same aromas with some roasted notes being present, along with a dark fruit flavor that melds with the complex richness that is based in cocoa and caramel with coffee notes.
Mouthfeel is full bodied, smooth, sweet, sugary, roasty, chewy, and dry. There is a mild thin feel about halfway through the swallow but overall its just a minor glitch in the grand scheme of this brew.

Bottle from World Market American microbrew pack. Pours black in color color. Little head. Looks rather thick on pouring. Oily roasted coffee aroma. Some sweet chocolate as well. Full flavored stout . Very nice roasted maltiness that really stands out. Kind of like a foreigned out sweet stout. Very tasty.

Chocolate and toasty malt aromas. Color so dark brown it really looks black. Tan head. Starts a bit tarry, passing to chocolate, ending with smoked malt flavors. Hops do not combine to finish with true bitterness, but they are there. Coffee finally seems to arrive. Pleasing, but more hop might improve.

Bottle:Black like ink with a small brown head and somewhat sticky lacing.  Tangy chocolate and burnt aromas as well as some coffee.  The taste is a tangified bitter chocolate covered coffee beans, mild on the coffee.  The body is pretty thick and it is smooth going down.  It leaves a great flavor in the mouth.  Yum.

Thin, dense light brown head of fine bubbles.  Recedes slowly with light carbonation.  Dark roastd coffee aroma with plenty of roasted malts, bitter dark chocolate and some carbon.  Color is black.  Roasty and bitter flavor.  Little bit of coffee and dark chocolate.  Kind of thin and slightly gritty.  Finish is roasty and coffeeish.  Ok but not all that special.

via trade with Buck Dich -  Pours a thick dark brown color with a nice light tan head.  Light lacing.  Has a strong roasted malt aroma.  Flavor is roasted malt, chocolate, and coffee.  A smooth but dry medium body beer.  Very nice.   Thanks Jordan.

Bottle from Joe (Degarth) Thanks!  Pours out a dark brown color, almost black, with a tan head.  Smell is full of malts and roasted flavors.  Taste is very similar, with a little chocolate and coffee present.  Very easy to drink, not bitter at all.  Pretty nice actually, my first beer from Wyoming.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2008 Sample shared with Odeed! Thanks, Jake! Nose very heavy with coffee and a chocolate note; opaque ebony body with a HUGE! tan head that did go away even when I finished, probably a little past the prime for this bottle (Nov date, no yaer) Smoky coffee flavor. 8/3/7/3/15 3.6 7/19/06
12 oz bottle from Supermarket Liquors Cheyenne; BB date Aug no year; Nose again with a lot of coffee and more chocolate, some roasty, toasty notes, and a hint of vanilla caramel; dark black with a medium cinnamon tan head which laces the glass nicely; flavor of coffee, chcolate, and light smokiness; body medium thick with a bit of bitterness and chcolate as the finish; Better bottle! 10/4/08

black body with a huge foamy head.(this was already a sine that this may be skunked)aroma was a nice mix of chocolate,coffee,and milk.flavor had a huge smoke taste upfront,that then was followed by the aromas making.although i could taste a little cardboard flavor in it.i bet a fresh sample of this would be awsome!

Bottle:  Courtesy of Duane via trade.  Big mocha aroma with some roasted malt.  Pours a dark brown with no transparency and a large tan head with good retention and nice lacing.  Lots of chocolate up front with light roasted malt.  Moderate roasted grain and coffee in the middle.  Light pine hopped finish.  A well balanced stout.  Very tastey.

Poured a very dark brown color with a large brown head.  Aroma of coffee and roasted grain with some sweet choclate notes thrown in for good measure.  the flavor was roasty and sweet.  Mild bitter finish.
solid well-balanced stout.  opaque with a khaki head which lasts to the bottom of the glass.  rich roasted barley aroma and a flavor to match.  very tasty!

Pour was thick with minimal had.  Thick, full bodied, oily stout with a chocolate and coffee aroma.  Had some of the winey characteristics of many stout - this one in a good way.  Overall, pretty darn good - not sure if Ill buy again, but pretty good.

Dark black with lots of foamy head (could have just been a poor pour).
Roasted sweet licorice, cherry in aroma. Starts sharp, mellowing to a smooth chocolate malt, then picking up a bitterness and mild soysauce flavor at the end. Moderately smooth, but nothing special.
Dark brown almost black pour with a thicked tanned head.  Aroma is strongly of coffee, taste is also primarily coffee and chocolate.  Also some maltiness and roasty flavors.  A solid stout overall.

Bottle: Black as night, large frothy light brown head, tufts of lacing.   Sweet milk sugar nose, pale roasted malts, very subtle hop.   Soft roasted malts, the lactose that was noticeable on the nose is much softer than expected, with a slight hop presense.   Seems like a standard type stout, not as rich as a Foreign Stout.   Clean, good, and quite easy to put back.   Soft chocolate malts on the exit.   Good stuff regardless.   Thanks Jordan!

It was quite a suprise to find this black liquid pouring from the bottle. Id been drinking so many lighter colored ales lately I almost forgot how thick a stout could be! The aroma of this stout kicks things off on the right foot with a strong dark bitter chocolate plus a roasted coffee bean nose. Appearance was just simply awesome, black, black and more black with light brown sugar color head. Mouthfeel was full bodied and thick. Flavor was bitter, coffee, chocolate and roasted malt. Quite tasty!

Courtesy of Bück Dich
<!-- P -->
Full roasty aroma has strong coffee and and chocolate notes. Deep black body with a long lasting two finger thick mocha head. Its a looker. Fore is almost salty and quite bitter with roasted notes. Chocolate is not present, but stiff coffee is abundant. The bitterness is big, but being from the roast it incorporates well into the beer and gives it a wetness you dont get with predominately hop bitterness. It could have more range and some underlying dark fruit accents, but it works well as it is.

12 oz bottle, via weeare138.  Pours a dark black colored body with some mahogany edges.  One finger dark brown head fades to a thin film leaving nice lacing.  Pretty robust aroma, heavy chocolate malt, burnt toast, coffee, a light dry yeastiness, and a touch of anise.  Flavor is balanced between chocolate and roasted malts mostly.  Finish is fairly dry with a dusty chalky lingering taste.  Medium bodied with a little too much prickly carbonation.  Overall, pretty decent.  A nice full flavored stout.  I wish the mouthfeel were a bit softer though.

What a pleasant surprise. I believe this was part of the Kingpin Christmas package. Good positve roasted malt , coffee aroma,nice intial coffee taste,plenty of dry roasted,got a little thin and bitter in the middle but overall a great effort
Pour was dark, with a thick and creamy dark head, Real nice lacing. Nose was roasted coffee and caramel. Real nice bittering to the taste. Smooth dryness to end this. Thank you DarkElf, Thank you.

(bottle - 12 oz) Dark black in color with a nice tan head. Roasted chocolate in the nose with hints of coffee to boot. Taste is very smooth and kind of bitter. Lots of roasted and toasted chocolate malts with a nice and roasty coffee finish. Very smooth at the finish. Thanks to Dan for this one.
Dark black body with thin ringing tan head.  Aroma is coffee grinds, cocoa, sweet.  Flavor is coffee grinds and chocolate.  Smooth, puckering palate.

Tap @ Jackson Hole. This stout was dry and into medium bodied but it was harsh & unpleasantly sharp. Maybe the mexican hummis or the lousy ceasar salad is throwing my taster off but I doubt it. Yes...rubber & tar.

Bottle. Black pour with an moderate frothy brown head that diminished slowly with good lacing. Heavy roasted malt, coffee and dark chocolate aroma. Full body with a smooth texture. Solid sweet chocolate roasted malt flavor with a long smooth small bitter finish. Soild stout.

Thanks to weeare138 for bringing this over to Toms place.  Pours a pure black with a lasting tan head with some lace.  Aroma is fruity with lots of roasted barley, coffee and chocolate.  Nutty roasted flavor, sweet with crystal and chocolate malt with a nice moderate bitter finish.  Very smooth overall, with a dry finiish and goes down easy.
Thanks to weeare138.  Pours a dark brown with an average tan lacing head.  Aroma of chocolate, lactose and light coffee.  Flavor or cocoa, coffee, sweet and nice.

Poured an opaque black color with a small, tan head that left light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of chocolate, coffee malts, and a strong breadiness (reminded me of brownies).  Taste of roasted malts, some chocolate, and some vanilla beans in the finish.
Pours black in color with a thin tan head.  Aroma is of coffee, chocolate, and malts.  Flavor is the same with a little alcohol warming.  My first Snake River brew and a decent one at that.

A very decent little stout, much better than what I was expecting I must admit.  Somewhat roasty intitially, which gives way to some sweet coffee and chocolate flavors, mouthfeel becomes quite creamy, and finishes up with just a big of a hop bite.

Bottle: Poured a pitch-black color stout with a medium deep brown head with excellent retention. Aroma of roasted malt with light sweet chocolate are easily detectable. Taste has a real creamy feel with a good dose of roasted malt and bitter hops. Lack a little something to make this truly great but still very enjoyable.

12oz bottle labeled best before Sept. Poured a dark black with red edges and an averaged sized light brown head. Aromas of roasted malts, chocolate, and coffee. Flavors follow the same. Light bitter coffee finish. Smooth body. I found this one to be quite tasty and well worth the $1.10 I paid for it.

Deep brown, quickly fading head, closing onto a 2/5. Bold nose that immediately reminds of tar, yet with a cream and coffee aspect that mellow the senses. Mellow rubbery hints peak through the heavily burnt malts. Almost plasticy in mouth, mostly due to a linear staleish development, quite roasty obviously, but in a coffeeish way more than anything else. Los of dark malts in there, which may explain the general enthusiasm. Mdium bodied, efficient carbonation. Good.
Pours a deep black with a little tan head.  Aromas of burnt coffee/chocolate.  Nice flavor of coffee/chocolate with a great touch of hops.

Black pour with a ring of light brown lace. Creamy aroma of coffee. Flavor of coffee with a roasty and bitter finish. The body has a medium thickness with a creamy mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. An interesting stout but I prefer my stouts more roasty and with some chocolate flavors.

The Lure:Suave coffee engulfs the fruity esters and malt roastiness. Simple but rich, inviting but without hurry.

The Festivities:Creamy cocoa and coffee thrive lavishly in the sexy mouthfeel. Yeast is apparent in the flavor profile, yielding some dryness and bitterness to match that of the roasted malts. Must be a quite filling pint from the tap.

Transcendence:A winter morning at home in your slippers.
GABF 05.  Pours black with a cream head and an aroma reminiscent of a porter-like sweetness.  Flavor is more of the aroma.  Great beer!
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Bottle.  Pours dark brown with a small tan head.  Amells of cooking chocolate, dough and grapes.  Taste is nutty with some small chocolatey notes.  Not bad.

aroma is slight, chocolate, burnt malts, a bit of hops, dark opaque brown body, head was slight as well, and faded quickly.  lots of burnt flavor in the flavor, with sweet chocolate and just a bit of hops coming out late, with just a bit of sourness that resembles a foreign stout more than anything.  there is a little coffee in the flavor, and that along with the hops lingers behind.  an enjoyable brew, could use a little more chocolate malt, it almost felt like they couldnt decide on the flavor they wanted.

Bottle poured an opaque black with ruby highlights and a small brown head. Aromas of dark chocolate, and a hint of cherries.Palate was smooth andlightly creamy. Flavors of bittersweet chocolate, with hints of coffee and oak with a dry slightly astringent finish.

Dark brown, with creamy tan head, light carbonation. Slightly acidic roast in aroma, some sweet malt around. Creamy mouthfeel with subdued coffee roast character. To this we welcome acidic -bitter woody flavours. Oak woody feel stay long on your lips.

Pours black with a tall brown head. Very roasty all the way through, slightly burnt chocolate note. Very smooth with a sweet coffee finish. Very well made stout with a nice hop finish cleaning out the the big sweetness in the end.

12 oz. bottle. Just as an aside, the bottle is reminiscent of the old steinie bottles. Pours a deep black with a nice frothy coffee colored head. Bitter chocolate aroma. Flavor is again bitter chocolate and roasted malt. Nicely balanced with the hops. A delicious brew.

came ina 12 oz brown short neck.
Very attractive looking dark, dark almost pitch black beer with purpleish toes, small very dark tan head good for the style.
Very strong and appealing aroma of dark unsweetned chocolate and sweet overripe black cherries.Cocoa powder and malted milk also
Weird after the great aroma I was expecting more, but what i got was a very sour , lactic tasting stout, with barelly a bit of chocolate flavour near the end and a very sweet aftertaste.
Mouthfeel was pretty mundane and too watery for the style.
I found this beer not very drinkable..a let down .
I hope this was just an odd bad bottle.

Thank you secret santa AKA Frylock, 12 oz bottle:  Pretty dark, almost black, with a lasting beige head.  Chocolate, roasty, and caramel in even balance in the nose initially, with roasty getting the nod in the end.  A bit chalky w/ an herbal hop as well as some sweet brown sugar and hints of perfumey alcohol.  Well balanced, chocolatey, roasty, and toasted malty!  Roasted bitterness in the finish with some herbal hop flavor and bitternes.  Toffee, sweet brown sugar, and a bit of dark grain tartness from mid palate into the finish which is semi sweet and roasty, chocolate, w/a lasting aftertaste.  Lower carbonation, smooth, and medium bodied.  Damn!  This is a fine stout and overall beer!!!!  Slightly sweet up front, well balanced overall, and lightly semi sweet in the finish.  This is a great beer for one taste or an entire evening.  Well done!!!!!!

I think I got this bottle from Springslicker. Pour black with a full brown head. Aroma of cocoa and roasted malt. Lightly sweet flavor full of chocolate. Light roastiness. Full bodied. I thought this beer rocked and I have no clue how old it is. Highly recommended.

12 oz bottle thanks Sammy.  Pitch black beer with a thin brown head.  Sweet plummy aroma, roast, molasses and a touch of toast.  Creamy texture.  Flavour is sweet and slightly fruity, licorice and a touch of pine as well.  Toast and faint vanilla along with moderate roastiness.  A bit thin, but still good.

Black w/ thin, frothy brown foam. Roasty notes of bitter chocolate & coffee on the nose w/ hints dark fruit. Medium feel-thin for style. Fairly simple flavour of chocolate & coffee w/ a light bitterness.

This beer is roasted deliciousness!  Incredibly black pour with a fluffy caramel head.  Roasted malts, bitter chocolate and toasted marshmallows on the nose.  Nice bitterness comes out in the flavor with a lingering burnt malt flavor and hop presence.  Similar to St Ambroise but without the velvet.  Delicious!
Awesome Stout.  It also helps to drink this beer in Jackson Hole.  The best place in the world.
Bottle. Black colour with a small baige head. Light roasted , chocolat aroma and a light sweet light roasted chocolat coffee taste. Medium body and a light dry finish.
Black pour with a tan creamy mocha head.  Aroma is a delicious mix of sweet chocolate and bitter coffee bitterness.  Palate is smooth and easy to consume. Not a real impressor but a good solid stout.

Pour is opaque blackish brown with a big tan head that faded slowly into nothing...smell is perfumey and toasty with quite a few chocolate flavors...the taste is pretty well balanced with bitterness and sweet malt...quite tasty...

An opaque brown beer with a collapsing brown head. The aroma is sweet roasted combined with light notes of malt and chocolate. The flavor is sweet roasted combined with notes of chocolate, and with a dry slightly woody finish. Nice.
Almost black in color with a rocky kahki colored head. Full roasty aroma with notes of bitter sweet cocoa. Roasted barley, licorice, and light cocoa. Finishes dry with hints of coffee. Nice stout.

Bottled.
Black coloured with a beige head.
Aroma of liquorice with roasted notes.
Flavour of liquorice with notes of chocolate and coffee.
I found it a competent stout compared to what I had before in the style, and just a better than average brew. Syrupy, some sourness, not watery but not a full mouthfeel either
Very dark brownish black color with a medium brown head. Very rich, roasty chocolate aroma and flavors. Slightly dry, bitter finish. Not very complex, but very tasty!

From a trade with Kevin. The head is light brown. The body is black as possible. The aroma is roasted nuts and oak. There is also a strong chocolate note. The smooth and creamy mouthfeel is complemented with dark chocolate. The finish has a strong roasted note. It is slightly dry at the end. Nicely balanced.

Boittle 12oz - Pours black with a 1/4 inch creamy tan head.   Aroma is chocolate and coffee and a touch roasted.  Flavor is semi-sweet chocolate and coffee.  Somewhat creamy yet a watery on the palate.  This is a decent drink but not an outstanding stout.

Poured to a a dark black body with a thick beige head that has excellent lacing.  The head never fully disapates.   The aroma is very chocolatey and roasted barley.  Theres also an angel food cake aroma.  Not very complex, however.  The flavor is very dry and roasty.  Espresso and semi-sweet chocolate chips with a touch of grass hops.  The palate is creamy and has  medium-thick mouthfeel but is too chalky.
Bottle.  Black color with a dark brown head that quickly laced.  A big roasted coffee aroma with a chocolate backbone.  A dry roasted semi-sweet flavor with a lingering chocolate and milk aftertaste.
Bottle. Black color with a beige head. Sweet chocolate flavours with a slight light body. Light bitter finish.
Bottled. Black coloured. Aroma of fruits and berries with notes of chocolate and coffee. Mild and malty flavour. Soft mouthfeel. Rather nice, but light.
Pours black/dark brown, with a tan head. Aroma is roasted malts, coffe, and sweet bitterness. Taste is full, roasted, with notes of coffe and dark chocolate.
Black with ligth brown head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, coffee and bitterness. Taste is coffee, chocolate and malt with burnt bitter lasting aftertaste.
Pours black with a light brown head. Aroma and taste of coffee, roasted malt and a bit of smoke and hops. A nice stout with a great body.
(Bottle)  Pours a black body with a small tan head.  Aroma of raosted malt, chocolate, and coffee.  Flavor of raosted malt and semi-sweet chocolate with a bitter finish.

Another fine beverage provided by the Iceman and kemster. It poured black with a beige head. The flavor was slightly bitter with some chocolate, coffee, and maybe even a bit of black cherries. A smokey mouthfeel is also there. Overall it was very good
This was decent.  No head really, but great dark brown color.  good malt, choclate, and only slight coffee in the taste.  i wasnt expecting much so this was pretty good kids.
Black as night with a brown head.  Lots of chocolate in the aroma, very thick.  kinda flat and soapy choclate, while still retaining some thickness to it. I dig it, go snake river.

Beer pours black with a nice tan colored head.  Aroma is sweet crea, milk chocolate, and strong coffee.  Flavor tilts to the coffee side with some nice roastiness as well.  Bit on the thin side palate wise.  Good stout.
Smells of bitter chocolate.  Pours a medium viscocity.  Tastes slightly thin and hoppy.  Fairly dry.  Smooth, coffee and toffee like elements carry the load.

pours black with a tan head. aroma is rich  sweet chocolate  and roasted malt. a very nice chocolate note that is very inviting .  taste is like dry cocoa and roasted malt that has been salted. enjyable. thick slightly oily mouthfeel .tha combines to make this a smooth drink. good hop level in the finish that brings out some coffee flavors. a nice stout. i look forward to having another.

Thanks to Buck Dich for this.  Pours Yaphet Kotto-colored, with a big tan head.  Aroma of malt, tons of chocoff, jalapeno oil, soy sauce/olive juice, licorice.  Wonderful, intense aroma.  Tastes rich, malty, with big chocoff, licorice, soy sauce, that jalapeno taste of Kalamazoo and Founders Breakfast Stout, and some scotch.  Very smooth, crisp palate.  Multi-tiered complexity in aroma and taste.  The finish gets dry, but the palate stays dense and complex, with great layers of flavor and texture.  Delicious.

This one surprised me on several levels...first from the rich mocha aroma and deep almost-black pour, I expected a very thick, smooth mouthfeel.  But it seemed a little thin, a little disappointing, a little watered-down.  But then it turned around again as far as the flavor was concerned...nice rich coffee, almost espresso, chocolate, dark rich roasty maltiness, and a pleasant, not overly done, sweet finish.  Nice job on this one.

Poured a rich, almost oil like black with a thin head. Aroma of chocolate malts. Taste isnt as full bodied as I expected from the pour, but medium none the less. Taste has bittersweet chocolate and espresso flavors. Finishes light, smooth and mellow.

Earthy, tootsie-roll chocolate aroma with "good coffee" notes.  Dry flavor - dark-roasted malt (coffee / dark chocolate) with fruity / dandelion hop notes.  Once you settle down with this beer you start to appreciate the malt-forward flavor.

ap: dakr black in color w/ a thin dark tan soapy looking head
ar: roasted malts, coffee, an odd chocolate smell not pure choc
pa: dry suprisingly carbonated, lightly creamy
fl: light choclate light malt a fairly light flavored dry stout tiny hop flavor.
a pretty good beer

Bottle from SpringsLicker.  Black in color.  Ephemeral brown head.  Light lacing.  Aroma is of deeply roasted grains bordering on a burnt smell.  Smooth mouthfeel.  Medium to full bodied.  Nice hop bitterness towards the end, very subtle.  A very nice stout.

This beer comes courtesy of beerguy101. Beautiful pour, reminiscent of a light black, dark brown color with a massive tannish brown head, creamy in texture...the type that dont just give way after a minute of sitting in your glass. Definitely a good degree of lacing as well with this beer. Aroma is fairly tame with roasted coffee beans, some chocolate and hint of malt with perhaps a tiny bit of lactose as well. Light and fluffy aroma. The flavor is medium bodied with a nice helping of carbonation and a surprisingly active level of hoppiness in the finish. Dry with a slight tingle of malty chocolate and grainyness in the finish. I also pick up a hint of that lactose again toward the finish, but overall this is very well executed. Big coffee flavors as it warmed...and being a lover of coffee, two thumbs up!
Ive been to wyoming... thus I am surprised that such an enjoyable brew could come from such a crap-ass place (maybe I was in all the wrong parts!)  well done =)

UPDATED: APR 3, 2005 The nose is taken over by dark roasted malts, bittersweet chocolate, coffee and alcohol. before you take a sip you know this is going to be a BIG beer! The aroma is intense.  Huge dark roasted malts that start out sweet but then turns slightly bitter. Lots of burnt coffee flavors in this beer as well without much chocolate. Much more caramel than chocolate. 

A very rich and assertive stout. Nice balancing! Nice Everything!

Bottle Pours a jet black with a small but dense tan head.  This settles out quickly leaving sparse chunky lacing.  Aroma is a terrific blen of classic Stout flavors. Coffee, molassas, bitter chocolate.  Very nice.  The coffee flavor is the most up front. Not much hops.  Lots of dark roasted flavors. Campfire, charcoal smoke.  Feel is very smooth but not too thick. As it warms up a bit, it mellows out more.  Burnt smokey aftertaste that is remarkably un-bitter.  A great showing from what I though would be just a po-dunk brewer.  Gonna have to make sure I give their other offerings a far chance.
Dark Color. Small Espresso Head.  Some Bitter Chocolate and Coffee. Decent Stout, but if you love Chocolate Bitter and Coffee Roasts Flavors in Your Stout, there are Better Ones Out There.

Pours a black color with a thin, tan head.  It has a bitter coffee aroma that turns into a more mild coffee and chocolate taste.  Middle-of-the-road amounts of barley It was pretty tasty, but not something Id search the ends of the Earth for.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2005 Nicely dark, almost black in color with a thick brown head.  Great chocolate, caramel, and roast coffee aroma, maybe a touch of spices and vanilla.  Thick, creamy body that fills the mouth smoothly.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.clubsofamerica.com/beerofthemonthc of the Month Club<font size=-1>
Great appearance, pours like motor oil and has a thick foamy grey head. Aroma is all chocolate with hints of coffee bean. Medium body with strong roasted flavors and coffee. Not bad.

Eclipse black color. Medium sized tan foamy head. Aroma is chocolate, vanilla and sweet. A medium bodied stout. Malts are very roasty, chocolate and coffee. Hops are slightly bitter. There is a separate overall bitterness to this beer that I cant quite figure out. It is kind of harsh and roasty at the same time, and there is a touch of cardboard as well. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter with a touch of cardboard.

Opaque appearance, good enduring  head of mocha foam. Malty, molasses aroma, cocoa and vanilla. Creamy intro, vanilla bean, chocolaty with roasted coffee, sweet balance (lactose?), strong bitterness in the finish.

Cask conditioned at the Jackson pub on my birthday, 7/16/04.  Flat black body with a slightly off white head arrived at the correct temp., slightly cool.  Aromas of chocolate, toasted malt, and coffee rolled out of it.  Huge mouthfeel.  Lots of chocolate and a little coffee with it along with a pretty hoppy but never biting touch.  long finish with very nice coffee notes the whole way through.  Almost too rich at times.  Kind of reminded me of Expo stout from Bells.
UPDATED: MAY 25, 2006 Rerate: Mild, malty chocolate aroma; moderate-full bodied;  roasty malts and espresso flavor; milky palate, though with a fairly bitter, lingering finish. Nice stout.

Looks the way I like beer to look: dark, almost black body with a tan, frothy head.  Dark chocolate and roasted coffee in the nose with some overtones of citrus.  Mouthfeel was medium, smooth, a little oily.  Flavor was semi-sweet chocolate and roasted coffee.  A respectable stout.
Black in color with a medium tan head. Roasted barley aroma with a subtle vegetable character. Flavors of roasted malt,chocolate,very malty.

black purple with a thin quickly discipating tan head. Nose is bitter with some malts but in general it is quite fiant. The taste is mostly bitter with a sharp kick right off the bat then calms down to be more malty and stubtle. THe body is nothing too exciting. Pretty darn average for a stout.
Great Stout!! Pours thick and black with a small but long lasting head. Pleasant bitterness with a big roasted flavor made this a nice companion with a bleu cheese filet on the grill.
a pleasntly seet rosted barley notes with hints of chocolate. Flavor was heavly roasted for the most part with some hop bitterness.

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2004 Bottle - Very dark with a very thin tan head with decent lacing.  Roasted barley is very strong in both the aroma and flavor.  Less than the typical amount of coffee.  There are several layers of hop flavor and bitterness, but it is not overpowering at all.  Hop bitterness lingers.  A very good effort. Enjoyable.
Thick, dark appearence with a roasty smell. Hints of coffee, with a thick, roasted taste. Lingering coffee aftertaste. Very good - I'd buy it again.
Dark black, maybe a tinge of red.  Nose is stouty, roasty with some chocolate.  No real coffee bitterness in the flavor, all chocolate and sweet.

Opaque black body with a medium tan head. Sweet roasted malt and a touch of chocolate on the nose. Flavor is kind of a let down after the aroma. Roasted malt and chocolate with some residual sweetness. Medium body. Not bad.

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2005 (9/28/05, 12oz bottle, best by November) Black body with small brown head.  Aroma is medium sweet, roasty, coffee, light cherry, anise.  Taste is moderately sweet, chococoffee, some burnt, light cherry.  Creamy medium body.  (6/4/6/4/12)

(4/17/04) Black body with medium beige head.  Aroma is medium sweet, roasty, chocolate.  Taste is medium sweet, roasty/light burnt, chocolate.  Medium body. (7/4/6/3/12)

Bottle.  Pours dark as can be with a big head and wafting aromas of roasted malts, charcoal, and dark chocolate.  Palate is thinner, but coating and bitter.  Very nice coffee notes in flavor with prune, licorice, tar.  Quick finish is bitter and dry.  Nice beer.

Nice black color,small brown head that lasted for a nice amount of time leaving a pretty decent lace.The aroma was Roasty and chocolatey with a mild coffee side maybe some dark dried fruit as well.Very dark flavor of coffee and dark bakers chocolate with some fruit and a decent hop presence coming through.Nice bitter finish of espresso,one very nice brew that maybe could use a little more in the body but overall does very nicely the way it is.Well worth having a few more around for later.Thanks got to Jpdipso for this fine brew.

12 oz bottle-pours pitch black with a HUGE relentless head, kinda like alpha klaus.  nice burnt/roasty aroma.  palate was very nice-reminds me of Bells stout, but just not quite as smooth.  nice burnt coffee/expresso/smokey flavors going on.  Definately one of Wyoming's best offerings.

Nice and strong burnt malt aroma with just a hint of alcohol.  Black in color with a very thin film of medium-brown head.  Good lacing.  Powerful roasted malt and coffee flavors.  Good rendition of what a stout should be.
A fine example of an American stout.  Looks perfect in a dimple mug,  very, very dark with a nice dark brown head.  Good aroma leads to a good taste and a nice creamy mouthfeel.
This Stout is what I can American or West Coast Stout.  The Stout part is excellent, but be prepared for a hop finish uncharacteristic of the British or Irish Stouts.

Pours almost black with a small tan head with a little oil slick. Roasted espresso and chocalate on the aroma. Strong coffee flavors, a touch of chocolate. Bitter finish that leaves you wanting a little more.
Very, very black, somehow a little maroon shines through.  The smell reminds me of the Ghirardelli Chocolate factory - sweet roasting chocolate.  Nice stuff, each sip leaves me wanting more.

Black color with a nice head retention and a nice dark tan color for the head. Aroma is lightly chocolate & roast, sweet milk and coffee. Flavor is balanced with a musty hop finish. Overall this is a very solid stout from a local microbrewery.
Pours very dark brown with a small dark tan head. Coffee and chocalate in the nose, some toffee. Strong coffee flavors, underlying chocolate.  Bitter finish and creamy palate. Nice stout.

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2003 Thick pour, frothy gravity-defying brown head and black body with murky brown edges. Aroma of dark chocolate, coffee beans and a burnt nuttiness. Robust flavor of espresso plus hints of chocolate and char. Nice medium hop bitterness. Warm, lingering aftertaste. A manly stout.

Dark brown with a small (quickly diminishing) light brown head. The aroma was somewhat fruity...maybe vegetables...sweet, with dark chocolate. The flavor was more on the roasty side with a strong coffee aftertaste. The feel was a little too thin, but refreshingly crisp on the tongue.

Aroma is earthy but not too strong and is dominated by chocolate and coffee although something seemed off. Appearance is dark dark brown. Flavor is smokey with a roasted malt aftertaste. Overall effect seems a bit thin.
Black with a dark tan head.  Aroma of wet vegetables, smoke, and roasted chocolate malts.  Very smokey, muddy, and earthy.  Wet dog and clay aroma ruins it.

Deep stout aroma--malty, chocolatey, but there is an edge to it that marks it out as potentially unpleasant in the tasting.  A Rogue-clone?  There is something like Porta-potty chemicals there, too.  The palate is moderately carbonated and yet slightly weak.  Classic flavors but again that aggressive edge that detracts from the overall enjoyment.  Nice color and suitably opaque body.

Appearance: This Wyoming beauty pours black with a frothy brown head.
Aroma: The nose is roasty, with a definite smell of bittersweet chocolate.
Flavor: It has a medium mouthfeel with an almost oily texture. The finish is dry. This is a straight ahead, dry stout. It's very nicely done.

Nearly opaque black with frothy tan head, minimal lace. Aroma hinted of burnt malts, molasses, bittersweet chocolate, butterscotch, toffee, and coffee. Taste has bittersweet twang and burnt malt presence. Undertones of berry, smoke and coffee. Dry finish. Medium to full-bodied with an oily and lively mouthfeel. A very nice straight forward dry stout. Flavors and aroma open up nicely when warming.

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2007 Frothy lacing looks like it should be at starbucks, roasted creaminess is very satisfiying.  Great cure for the cobwebs left by drinking too many others over the weekend.  I think I have ultraspank to thank.  Rerate: a six pack hand delivered from a Wyoming archeological dig (as well as many others!)  They travel well and even better in my luggage to an off campus teaching expediation of my own.  Very nice company in all aspects.
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: Nearly opaque balck with a glimpse of garmet on the edges. Dark heavy head of tan bubbles. Sweet roasted malt, light chocolate and hint of vegetable. Sweet dark chocolate start that turns to a bitter acidic amelgomation of goo. The hops flavors are to sweet and don't seem to meld well with the dark malts.
Quite good.  Better be for $10.99 a sixer!  A little hard to find.  I'll buy it again though, if I can find it.  Excellent representation of what a stout should taste like.

This brew poured a small head os finely sized mostly diminishing brown colored bubbles that left behind a opaque dark black uncarbonated body.  It had a strong coffee malt aroma with a very smooth mouthfeel and a strong coffee flavor.
Thanks Captaincouger(Tom) for this brew.  Very dark brown with a moderate brown head.  A lot of roast flavors here.  Coffee, toffee, etc.  It is well balanced. Even balanced on the finish.
Another great big coffee-like stout.  Initial  flavor is wonderfully intense, but seems to mellow as it is drunk.  A rather thin palate for the amount of flavor.
Great roasted barley aroma.  Midnight black color and tan head.  Big toasted and roasted flavor.  Very well balanced with a long finish.  An excellent standard stout.

dark dark but not completely black,  gets point for a nice dark foam.  Ended up inhaling some trying the get the aroma.  We'll file that under too much carbonation.  Roast malt flavor with a slight coffee flavor.  I like the flavor but i think the carbonation brings it down compaired to most stouts
UPDATED: FEB 6, 2004 opaque body with a light brown head. coffee and roasted aroma. Tasted  roasted, bitter, and creamy. With a good strong carbonation with a bitter ending. I like it a lot.

Rich roasted nose of  chocolate, medicine, caramel, oats, and flowers.  The brew pours a dirty motor oil black.  The solid brown creamy head is fully lasting with good lacing.  The bittersweet chocolaty flavor is excellent with a light acidity and a long bitter full finish.  The chewy body is syrupy and soft, the finish feels clean.  Outstanding.
Black,thick brown head. Roasted malt alcohol nose. Dry roasted chocolate malt flavor. Chewy
Pours like thick motor oil.  Strong roasted coffee bean aroma and flavor.  The body is lightly carbonated and malty.  It has a dry moderately bitter finish.  Enjoyable, but average for its style.

Nice aroma, particularly smoky, dark fruits, alcohol, but slight metallic tang. Nice dark black beer with brown foamy head that dissipated quickly. Medium oily body and medium-light carb. Metallic tang - copper. Smoky and meaty, dark roasted malts with a little bitterness and sourness. A decent stout.
Chewy, roasty, full bodied the way a stout should taste.  It perfectly balances roasty malts, with complementary hops, and a slight chocolatey flavor to an excellent (almost benchmark) stout.
Jet black color, nice clingy head, smells of chocolate, much too sweet unbalanced.

This beer poured an amazing jet black color and formed a very nice dark brown, bubbly head that left some nice lace. I had an aroma of malt, hops and coffee. The flavor was of malt and coffee. The finish was a touch bitter and had elements of the coffee. A very nice stout.
This beer was 3 months past the expiration but still held up.  Poured nicely and held the head for several minutes.  Flavor was smooth roastiness.  Fairly malty.  Id like to try this less aged.
Pitch black color with a dark brown head.   Tiny bubbles dance down     the side of the glass.   Roasty malty taste, but not overpowering.
UPDATED: JUN 26, 2004 On tap GABF '02:  Black with a good sized head, Big coffee aroma, oily mouthfeel, ends slightly sweet.
Pitch black with massive head. Medicinal coffee aroma. Big coffee taste. Roasted bitter aftertaste & really thick. Thanks Dogbrick you are a dead set legend.

similar to an astronomical black hole, the darkness of this beverage doesnt merely preclude luminance, its vortex of imploding atoms actually begins to suck the light out of the environment: my lamp flickers in its presence. what makes it spiffy tho, is the noble bloom of head, tanned as the brittle pages of an aged manuscript, ostentatious as a bejeweled crown, lasting as a geographic benchmark.   i have here a sample six months on the far, elderly side of the freshness date, but i think thats what makes it good: i used to drink this at the brewery and i thought it was harsh and boorish. now, time has taught it some grace and humility, it has some mello charm: nose has nutty, bitter chocolate and rye bread notes blending with subtle charcoal. nice carbonation waltzes the full bodied dry malts through a succession of soy, coffee and burnt raisins quickly to a sharp hop cresendo. i think i like it: and im not just pining for fall in jackson hole either. well, maybe a little.

Dark black, opaque body; chocolate 1/4 inch head, rings of lace as the glass is drained.  Sweet chocolate aroma.  This started off slighty sweet and roasted but quickly added these "charred" flavors that nearly ruined it. The finish was short and sweet.
UPDATED: AUG 26, 2003 Very black with a brown head. Roasted malt aroma. Pretty sweet and coffee like.
I was somehwat impressed with this stout. Im not sure why, but i wasnt expecting much. Nicely done. However a bit chalky
Nice color and smell.  Nice roasted flavoer with a touch of carmel.  A very nice all around beer.

This was a pretty good stout.    A nice dark black color with an exceptionally strong chocolate aroma.  After that, the flavor was mostly a chocolate malt with some roasted grain flavor as well.  It wasnt really that bad, but Id prefer a Mackeson Triple stout

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2007 Bottle. Head is initially average sized, frothy, brown, mostly diminishing. Body is dark brown to black. Aroma moderately malty (roasted/burnt grain, dark chocolate, husks), with a note of ash. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter, unclean/husky. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Very poor aftertaste, as it has always had, and a simple burnt aroma. Still have never had a good sample, despite it winning awards periodically and getting some high ratings on occasion here as well.  I dont see it.

Dark and interesting.  Warm coffee aroma.  It has a thin feel to it though.  I mean, it tastes really good - but for as dark as it is and that nice warm aroma, it tastes thin - if that is possible.  With most beers this dark, I feel like I am drinking a milkshake - but this was thin - not unpleasantly so - it is just a strange observation.

Pours like a glass o road tar. In other words, its very dark. Thin and quickly diminishing head. Satisfying coffee/roasted barley aroma, and a nice hops/malt balance made for good drinking. Glad I got a sixer of this.

Somebody send Oakes another bottle.  Its not a world beater, but its not a bleh either.  Nicely roasted, sweeter malt with some cloying cherry, but mostly interesting  molasses.  It has some rougher edges to be sure - some from hops, some from the challenging carbonation.  Id say it gets the nod over Moose Juice, the other Jackson Hole stout.

Almost non-existant aroma.  Slight notes of roasted malt and coffee I really had to struggle to discern.  Flavor profile is not much better.  Not watery, just not many exceptional flavors.  Some roasted malt, chocolate, coffee and slight smoke but I had to struggle to find them.  Bitter finish.  Black as night with a large milk chocolate colored head I found appealing.  Altogether, not a stout Im eager to try again.

Very dark beer with nice, dark head.  Initial flavor is roasty/coffee balanced with alot of hops.  As it warms the alcoholic notes come out in the finish.  This is a good stout with all the right flavors, if maybe a little less complex than my favorite stouts.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2006 Jet black colour.  Rocky head.  Very attractive stout.  Chocolatey, slightly lactic, a bit roasty aroma.  Distinctly chocolatey flavour with delicious sweet maltiness.  This combination of complexity and drinkability is rare.

My god, this beer is blacker than the dark side of the moon! Creamy dark tan head. Chocolate nose. Soft and smooth on the palate. Roasty & toasty, with some coffee tones and some dark-chocolate sweetness. I dont see it as being watery. Sometimes a soft mouthfeel might be misinterpreted as watery, but the flavor is fairly robust. Bitter - almost sour - finish, which lasts... and I liked it. Maybe a little acrid, but I like em like that; call me weird.
gorgeous brew....big head that lasts. chocolate dominated flavor initially with coffee notes lingering on the palate....very tasty
big and dark with a dark brown head.  creamy with a super dark chocolate taste balanced by a nice coffee taste.  a good stout.
Black. Relatively neutral. Some bitterness. Didnt leave me very impressed.
A very good stout.  All kinds of different roasty and nutty flavors.  The color was opaque and the mouthfeel was thick but incredibly smooth.  Rung in 2002 with this gem thanks to Gusler!

Ahhh...a home grown product. Thank goodness
I get this one all the time. Snake River does have
some fine brews...I do miss the Draft Lager that was
around a couple of years ago.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2007 Penetrable black. Sticky burnt-pearl foam leaves chunky lace all the way down the glass.  Expressive orange-infused chocolate and salted licorice aromatics. Slightly phenolic. Firm carbonation expands on the palate. Dryly grainy upfront with an assertive blend of bitter cocoa and pungently earthy roast which bolsters the dryness. Fluffy nougat pillars the center, but some graininess exudes beneath.  Plummy fruitiness echoes that of the acidic char.  Buttery caramel softens the graininess and adds depth. Brash whispers of hop bitterness waver in and out. Flaked barley imparts a pleasant oily java effect before finishing slightly tarry, but mostly dry and light on its feet with crunchy char, smoke, and java. A bit grainy and not quite soft or elegant enough, but an enjoyable stout nonetheless.

text: A nice, heavy stout.  Not very think (a bit watery).  A small hop profile.  Very enjoyable.
A quality stout that is in my top 25 stouts, roasty, toasty, creamy thick chocolate tasting beer that is a well balanced brew.
